Package infodynamics.measures.discrete

Class BlockEntropyCalculatorDiscrete

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.discrete.InfoMeasureCalculatorDiscrete
      • infodynamics.measures.discrete.EntropyCalculatorDiscrete
        • infodynamics.measures.discrete.BlockEntropyCalculatorDiscrete
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    SingleAgentMeasureDiscrete
    public class BlockEntropyCalculatorDiscrete
extends EntropyCalculatorDiscrete

    Block entropy calculator for univariate discrete (int[]) data (ie computes entropy over blocks of consecutive states in time). Implemented separately from the single state entropy calculator to allow the single state calculator to have optimal performance.

    Usage of the class is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator: BlockEntropyCalculatorDiscrete(int, int);
    2. Initialise the calculator using initialise();
    3. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using one or more calls to sets of addObservations(int[]) methods, then
    4. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average entropy: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • local entropy values, such as EntropyCalculatorDiscrete.computeLocal(int[]);
      • and variants of these.
    5. As an alternative to steps 3 and 4, the user may undertake standalone computation from a single set of observations, via e.g.: EntropyCalculatorDiscrete.computeLocal(int[]), EntropyCalculatorDiscrete.computeAverageLocal(int[]) etc.
    6. Return to step 2 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    References:

    • T. M. Cover and J. A. Thomas, 'Elements of Information Theory' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1991).
    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
